speaker: Dr Stone
theText: I rise to support the Prime Minister’s motion relating to bushfires. I join with11200 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 6 February 2003 stage, it is impossible to quantify the cost to the nation of the assets that have been burnt. Of course, fires are a natural part of the Australian landscape. We live in a fire-prone environment, with periods of peak fire danger occurring in particular seasons in all parts of the continent and Tasmania. The sustaining of much of our unique biological megadiversity is dependent on a regular, but not too frequent or intense, burning regime. Australia’s Indigenous owners developed systems of highly effective fire management to modify and sustain the landscape in order to regenerate and increase their food supply. Fire was also used for communication and improving travel routes. Indigenous societies also knew the importance of reducing fuel loads from time to time to lessen the risk of more intense destructive wildfires that killed rather than regenerated species. We are now in the midst of a very extensive and prolonged drought. This has been accompanied by some of the highest temperatures on record, and these circumstances have combined to create this extreme fire risk and outcome. They have resulted in some of Australia’s most extensive and destructive fires. The last time we saw such devastation was in the fire disasters in New South Wales during the terrible drought of 1901. All the fires have not yet been put out, and it would seem that they could be as severe as the fires of 1926 and 1939. Contemporary fire management, particularly the use of cold burns or prescribed burning to reduce hazard and for biodiversity conservation, is complex and controversial. When the last fire is out and everyone has had time to recover, public land managers, policy makers and experts need to sit down and analyse the behaviour of the fires in areas treated differently in terms of hazard reduction and other fire management efforts. The John Howard-led government has committed $25 million to the new Commonwealth Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre. This was announced just last year. Participating agencies include the Bureau of Meteorology, state and territory land management agencies and fire authorities, the CSIRO, universities and Emergency Management Australia. Obviously, that CRC will have very important work to do. In the wake of the recent disasters, some have called for a national inquiry into bushfire prevention. Assessment of the environmental impact of the 2003 fires will require evaluation of firefighting strategies. Mechanical intervention using earthmoving equipment, backburning and the use of fire retardants play an important role in wildfire suppression, but we need to better understand the environmental impacts in the short and longer term. We also need to note where the fires began. At this time, a lot of people are focusing on national parks or state parks and their fire management regimes. Interestingly, the New South Wales fire service reports that, recently, less than 10 per cent of the fires that started in national parks moved outside them. Twenty-four per cent of fires in parks started outside them and moved into the parks. Alarmingly, 21 per cent of these wildfires were caused by lightning but the rest were caused by arson or suspected arson. Most of these fires could have been avoided, and this is a shocking statistic. It would seem that, while many Australians risk their lives to save others in fires, there are too many other Australians with criminal intent prepared to put lives, property and biodiversity at risk. Fireproofing our great country is not possible-and, besides, many ecosystems have evolved to depend on fire for regeneration-but perhaps we are moving into a new era where the new Bushfire CRC will be covering new ground with the research it will undertake. I am referring to climate change. In 2002, Australia’s Third national communication on climate change reported that the incidence of wildfire in Australia could be expected to increase with global warming. The number of days of extreme and high fire danger could be expected to increase. Insurance and finance industries are re-evaluating risks associated with insurance in Thursday, 6 February 2003 MAIN COMMITTEE 11201 light of changing climate and projections of increased property damage through events such as fire. Possible responses by insurance companies to an increase in the frequency of such events include raising premiums, restricting coverage and withdrawing from some areas of insurance with the highest risk. Obviously, any such decisions will have significant economic and social ramifications. We also have to take serious action in terms of our public lands. The interim report of the Independent Scientific Committee on An assessment of the values of Kosciuszko National Park noted in a chapter on fire: Specific areas prone to high-intensity wildfire can be accurately predicted, so it is possible to preclude developments and investments in these lands, by using restrictions similar to those applied in areas subject to other natural hazards such as flooding and landslip ... Such measures could include: strategic fuel reduction (including prescribed burning) ... ; exclusion of residential and other asset development in fire prone lands; making assets fire resistant; ensuring that those involved in fire management have a basic understanding of fuel dynamics and fire physics ... All of this work needs to be done, and I am sure it will be. Certainly a one size fits all strategy cannot be adopted for fire in Australia. The extensive annual controlled burning for ecosystem management in Kakadu, for example, is quite different from the fire strategies which are aimed at protecting people, plants and infrastructure in the Australian National Botanic Gardens. Fuel loads and fire behaviour are influenced by many factors, including the structure of vegetation cover, weather, the terrain and the history of land management in the area. However, the interactions between type of fuel, temperature, wind speed and direction, and fire spread can mean that-despite the very best efforts of firefighters on the day, the forward planning of land managers and the fire plans of householders-a tragedy like the ACT fires can still occur. A city fringe wildfire in gale force winds, in tinder-dry drought conditions and with temperatures like the temperatures this January will inevitably be disastrous. I also wish to refer to the role of the Bureau of Meteorology as it struggled to keep up with the demands of so many fire fronts and the increasing need to do more accurate forecasting to assist in the firefighting effort. They coped with the demands in a magnificent way. I am proud to report the accuracy and the speed with which they were able to assist the firefighting effort with forecasting. In particular, the Victorian Regional Forecasting Centre has been working seven-day, round-the-clock shifts. To give you one example of the intensity of their work, on 15 January there were eight uncontrolled fires, 28 fires contained and 65 fires controlled, mostly over north-east Victoria in mountainous terrain. Forecasting was required for all of those fire fronts and in conditions where often, for example, the winds blowing in the valleys were blowing from a different direction to the winds at the top of the mountains. In addition to forecasting accurately in a timely manner for the firefighting, because of the smoke and haze, aviation forecasting has also been a particular challenge. The Bureau of Meteorology has been performing magnificently to ensure the greatest possible public safety. I want to repeat that we are in difficult times with our fires but Australians are not strangers to the devastation of fire in this country. Fire is a natural phenomenon. However, with humaninduced global warming, we can expect more fires in the future. We need to understand those fires better, understand the needs of ecosystems and also understand the human psychology that puts some individuals with a matchbox in their hands beside a flammable heap of material in the bush, with no regard for the lives of their fellow Australians. I very strongly support the motion by the Prime Minister. We are a great country with great people. This fire season effort yet again demonstrates what real Australians can do. 11202 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 6 February 2003 devastation wreaked not only here in Canberra but throughout the continent. A couple of years ago Sydney was absolutely ringed by bushfire. Our biggest city, with the largest population, had at its very core bushfires of an intensity and immensity that could hardly be imagined. People found it very difficult to comprehend just how significant a natural force this was. Year after year, some years more than others, this has come to the fore. There have been responses to that over time. The latest response of significance was in 2002, when, after more than 100 years of this federal parliament, a specialist body was finally set up to have a look at the nature of bushfires from a federal perspective. In part, that is because responsibility for dealing with bushfires, controlling them and taking care of the environment locally has largely been put at the feet of state governments and of local council or shire bodies. What we do know is that it is fundamental that we have a Commonwealth research institute to look deeply into the very nature of the Australian landscape and how it has changed and that it come up with a better means of dealing with Australian bushfires. I think the fundamental problem we face is very simple: we do not know very much at all about Australia’s landscape and how it operates. Despite being surrounded by 600 different species of eucalypts, we do not understand their fundamental nature, we do not understand how they operate, we do not understand how to manage them and we do not understand how to live with them. And yet, at state and federal level, we have had public policy made that should be based on those fundamental understandings. Looking at the early history of Australia, population from the West-from Englandstarted here in 1788, after Cook’s discovery 18 years earlier, after previous discoveries by other Europeans. From the evidence, it used to be thought that Aboriginal migration to and population of Australia occurred between 25,000 and 40,000 years ago. That was upped to probably about 60,000 years ago. There is some evidence that it could have occurred 100,000 years or so ago but, for most of the modern period-the period of homo sapiens-the Aboriginal people have been here and have managed the land. But, since 1788, the Australia that the Europeans came to has dramatically changed. We know that there is far less forest here in Australia than when Captain Cook first sighted the shores of eastern Australia. We know that there is far less forest that is tropical rainforest based, because we know what was culled out of the northern part of New South Wales in the cedar-getting that was one of the first great industries in Australia. We also know that that has caused a dramatic change in the nature of the forests that are left, and it has in fact encouraged the takeover of those areas that were temperate or subtropical rainforest by eucalypts. We know also that, apart from the dramatic diminution in the extent of our forestation, it has probably changed. Early on, when I was a history teacher dealing with the very early depiction of Sydney and the colony of New South Wales from 1788 to about 1810, there was a view prevalent that the Australia that Cook saw and that Phillip helped to establish a colony in was just the same as the Australia of today and that the bush then was the same as in the Australia we have today, except that there was more of it. It was thought by some historians, but certainly by art historians, that what was painted of early Australia-the depictions we got first from rough sketches by people on Cook’s voyages and later in the works of Tench and others, and the very first representative pictures-emerged as being so different to what we know Australia to be because English people were doing the paintings. The central idea was that you held within your head a certain view of what the environment was like. If you were Eugene von Guerard or one of the other early painters of Australia, the

speaker: Mr Hatton (Blaxland) (11.49 A.m.)
theText: Once again, this summer we have seen enormousThursday, 6 February 2003 MAIN COMMITTEE 11203 expectation was that you would paint a parklike depiction of Australia, with afforestation that had virtually no undergrowth but very short grass. That is an indication that these artists were prisoners of their ideas of what landscapes should look like because they came from England or the Continent. There is a very strong set of reasons why you would expect that to be true. But later evidence that was advanced helped, I think, to change the possibility in terms of that picture. The best expression of that was Robert Hughes’s work-a major and monumental work on the foundation of the colony of New South Wales. That work provided the first information that there might be something more fundamental than that-that it was not just the way that Pieters saw the land. More importantly, in his work called the Future Eaters, Tim Flannery, an environmental biologist, put forward a different view not only of the operation of fire and the way in which the Australian landscape was managed and developed by the Australian Aborigines but also of the fundamental place of large marsupials in the control of that environment. In an article a week or so ago titled ‘Bushfire of our vanities’-and I am indebted to the Parliamentary Library for finding this at very short notice-Flannery encapsulated the central argument that he put in the Future Eaters. He said that, instead of thinking of that environment, that parklike atmosphere of Sydney and its surrounds in 1788, as being an aberration, there is another explanation. The explanation is that, when the explorers-because it was not just the people drawing the pictures-said that they could walk through areas of Sydney that were virtual parkland, they meant it. They meant it because fire had been used to create an environment in which Aboriginals could hunt large and small marsupials through the grasslands. The dense nature of the eucalypt forest that we have around Sydney now was not the case in 1788. He makes the point in his article that Cook found a continent wreathed in fire from one end to the other. From Western Australia to the eastern seaboard, Australia was dominated by fire-probably not the raging fires that we see today but more controlled burns. It took most of our European history before we came to a fundamental understanding that we need to use Aboriginal methods of management to control the forest. Based on the foregoing, I make this fundamental point: it is not wise of the government to rush forward and belt the daylights out of people who have argued for a green perspective on forest policy. No-one knows how we should properly manage Australia’s forests. It is my inclination-I have argued it in the past-that we need to look extremely closely at this, because I do not think there is much sense in totally locking up all of our forested land and just letting it be. If we do, we would not be managing the land in the way it has been managed for millennia. That would allow a situation in which we would have the almost total devastation of our great forests and of our lands as a result of raging wildfires. The point that Flannery finally makes with regard to this is that it is not very smart not to take into account the fact that our settlements have moved directly into the path of our major bush areas. We in opposition call upon the government to support the work of the Bushfire CRC in starting the fundamental steps to understanding the true nature of Australia’s environment and the true nature of our bush. The government should not just run off in an ad hoc way and say, ‘Let’s blame people because this stuff has been locked up.’ It should look at different ways of managing our environment so that the inflammatory nature of the Australian bush and its eucalypts can be tamed to our purposes in much the same way that the Europeans tamed their environment in continental Europe itself. those families who have been affected by bushfires and to those who are still battling blazes in south-eastern New South Wales and northern Victoria. speaker: Mr John Cobb (Parkes) (11.59 A.m.)
theText: I wish to express my deepest sympathies to11204 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 6 February 2003 time the captain of our local fire brigade in one of the worse bushfire areas in New South Wales, the Cobar Shire. When a fire really goes, it goes. I can remember in 1984-85 in the worse fires we had, three times in one day the fire went clean over the top of us. You cannot fight a fire in that situation. ‘Firefighting’ is the worse explanation of what brigades do that I have ever heard. You set up defences and when the fire dies down you try to control it. I think the crux of the issue that we are discussing is the defences and the preparations you make to control fire. In New South Wales in particular, every year we wait with bated breath to see how the fire season will play out. This has been a particularly horrendous season, and it is far from over. In some areas the fire has been stifled by the drought. A lot of grassland has been eaten out and many areas will not carry fire at all. Luckily, in those circumstances there is insufficient fuel to be a danger to humans or to wildlife. But in forested areas the drought has provided fuel for the fires. The forest fuels are abnormally dry. The natural barriers like the moist swamps, the creeks, the rivers and the shallow lakes are simply not acting as they normally do. Fuel is the most important element of a bushfire. Fuel determines the intensity, speed and heat of a bushfire. The important characteristics of a fuel that determine fire behaviour are the fineness of the fuel and the structure of the fuel bed. In actual fact, those things that lie on the forest floor or on the timbered country’s floor are the things that will determine whether or not a fire gets going. Grass is obviously the simplest form of fuel. I have seen grassfires travel faster than human beings are able to get around them and, in mallee or timbered areas, far faster than the possibility of getting around in front of them were you so foolish as to try to do so. The forest litter bed is the part which is most important in determining how fast or where a forest fire will spread. Research has found that doubling the fuel in the forest will double the rate of spread and quadruple the fire intensity. Note that I am talking about what happens in forests, not on farmland and not on privately held land. It is very easy to understand why people want to live in an idyllic forest-like area. They tend these days to want to build their homes in those areas. While I shudder when I see the danger that they put themselves in, it is easy to understand why they want to live in such areas. But it is the job of governments and authorities to protect people from that danger. For far too long, environmental correctness has been given precedence over safety, over human life and over the value of the assets that people in the community have and depend on. If the status quo continues, especially in New South Wales, we will simply see a repeat of this next year and the year after and so on. Systematically reducing ground fuel by prescribed burning-in other words, hazard reduction-is the only way to reduce the incidence and severity of bushfires. It is impossible in a country like this to reduce bushfires to the extent that they are not going to happen. We live in a dry country; we accept the dangers that come with it, but there are limits. Reduction burning can obviously be unpleasant and it causes pollution to some extent, so there is a built-in political resistance to it-especially among those in the metropolitan areas. But simply standing around preserving aesthetic values comes at one heck of a cost. When the bushfires hit and homes in the outer regions suffer from them, very little resistance can be offered. It is too late to try to deal with a fire when it is on your doorstep. The only way we can deal with it is by prevention. A senior principal research scientist with the CSIRO, Phil Cheney is one of Australia’s foremost bushfire experts. He spent 40 years trying to convince Australians of the need for hazard reduction. In the last two summers, there has been an enormous loss of assets and an enormous loss of life. In New South Wales, even in the Goobang Valley in my own electorate, Thursday, 6 February 2003 MAIN COMMITTEE 11205 fires have led to incredible losses. They burned in the national park for a very long time and, as a result, we lost incredible amounts of farmland, stock and opportunities for people to earn their living. So many people have been affected over the last 12 months. In October 2002, a lady was killed in Ballandean in south-east Queensland; also in October, a death occurred in Abernethy, near Cessnock in New South Wales; in December 2002, a man was killed north of Sydney; in January 2003, four people were killed in the Canberra fires; and, also in January, a man was killed north of Perth in Western Australia. The estimated cost of the Canberra fires alone now stands at nearly $300 million. Five hundred and thirty-odd houses have been destroyed, and 800 have been damaged. Twelve thousand hectares of pine plantations were destroyed. I could go on and on. It is interesting to look at what has happened over the past few years-since 1997, in particular, when the Rural Fire Service legislation was introduced into New South Wales. Fire hazard laws were recently introduced by the Carr government subsequent to that, to give the New South Wales government or the Rural Fire Service greater powers to force landowners to clear their fire hazards. The only problem is that Premier Bob Carr did not introduce this until 1 August, and that is little use when the bushfire season started before that. I make the point now-and I will make it again later-that it was introduced only for landowners on private land. Bob Carr conceded that there were problems with it addressing only private land-holders but failed to recognise the extreme shortfalls posed by the timing of his legislation. Even more, he failed to admit what the real danger is. The real danger to homes and to farmland is what comes out of national parks. To simply give power over all private land but not public land defies the laws of common sense. Why do you give authorities power over those who have the most interest in safeguarding their assets, their families and loved ones and not give those authorities power to deal with those who have the least interest in the lives of others and their private assets and homes? It defies common sense and it flies in the face of what has happened since 1997 in three bushfire seasons. It is time to stop bowing to environmental correctness. Everyone wants to look after the environment and have a decent place to live, myself included. But preserving the status quo will cause more environmental destruction and actually go against what it is that Bob Carr is trying to do. What he is trying to do is preserve the vote of those in the cafe set in the metropolitan areas, who mostly do not have to deal with the issue; the rest of us do. When you think of the number of lives lost, the houses destroyed and the thousands of hectares of good farmland burnt around national parks since 1997, it defies imagination. I would like to go back to 1997 briefly, because that was when the Rural Fire Service legislation was introduced. I was involved in trying to get some sense out of the legislation, which was not designed to give the ordinary person input into what should be done. At that time, we tried to give ordinary people who live with and deal with fires an input and the ability to go to the minister to say when the processes of the ministerial advisory council were not working. But because the government and the commissioner-who is still the commissioner today-in New South Wales were terrified of anybody else having a direct link to the minister on fire procedural matters in New South Wales, they did a deal with the environment lobby in the upper house to prevent an alteration to that legislation which would have allowed those involved in the rural fire situation greater transparency and access to the minister. They did a deal with the environmental lobby, which meant that the threatened species 11206 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 6 February 2003 legislation had to be taken into account by private land-holders, national parks and everybody who-if any law of common sense applied-would do hazard reduction burning. The result is what we have had-and what we told them we would have-since 1997: lives lost, incredible amounts of farmland lost and incredible numbers of houses lost around Sydney and Canberra. If you do not give those who are charged with looking after fire regulations or the practical aspects and processes of them-in the case of New South Wales, the Rural Fire Service-the power to control government, public or crown land as well as private land, you are not going to approach a solution to the dilemma of losing lives and property to fire. Bob Carr catered to the votes of the extreme green environmental lobby and refused to give power over national parks to those who must have it. National Parks and Wildlife Service’s job as they see it is to preserve the status quo. Not only do they block off entries; they fill in dams and do everything they possibly can to make national parks, in a sense, unattractive to humans. That obviously makes it a lot harder to go in there to travel around and find water when it has to be used. In the same way, they try to discourage animals from watering in parks but have them watering in the farmland outside. It is not conducive to public safety, nor to the assets of the rest of us. I believe that those in charge of national parks are certainly very decent human beings. But until those who understand and are charged with the fire prevention safety of the state-and other states as well-are forced to do those things that have to be done to set up barriers against future fires, there is going to be no sense in it. I have had National Parks in New South Wales say to me, ‘We simply couldn’t do fire prevention burning-it was too green.’ Any farmer in Australia could tell them how to spray and burn within a week in any situation where it is too green-it is not hard to do. We need to have the willingness, the foresight and the long-term vision to do it in order to save lives and assets. that have been made by the member for Parkes are very important. In the aftermath of what is clearly a tragedy for many areas of Australia-many parts of New South Wales, Victoria and, particularly, Canberra-it is imperative that people look at the way we are going to avert any future tragedy. We need to ensure that we manage our parks and our bush in a way which will prevent or mitigate the likelihood of such occurrences happening again. It is critical for authorities and governments at every level to determine the best way to ensure these things do not occur. I do not think it is acceptable for people to rush to judgment. It is necessary that this matter is looked at dispassionately. Indeed, that can be done if there is goodwill; and it should be done. I was not listed to speak on this matter. I rise briefly to put on the record my appreciation of the SES and CFA in Gisborne and in other areas of the electorate of Burke, who were called upon to put out what ended up being quite minor fires in my electorate. Indeed, I record my appreciation of those volunteers and professional firefighters from the region who went to other areas to ensure that there would be critical assistance for the homes and the lives of people in north-east Victoria. To those wonderful volunteers and to all those people from my electorate who involved themselves and went to fight the fires in Gisborne or beyond their own areas, I say thank you very much. fires have devastated large tracts of land, destroyed homes, caused injury and on some occasions caused loss of life. This year has been no different. Bushfires have raged through various areas of the Pearce electorate, including Bullsbrook, Swan View, Lancelin and others. speaker: Mrs Moylan (Pearce) (12.15 P.m.)
theText: Every summer in my electorate of Pearce, bushThursday, 6 February 2003 MAIN COMMITTEE 11207 hard to train and prepare their volunteer teams. I have been involved in these planning meetings to get an idea of what actually goes on; I know the tremendous work that goes into the planning meetings, where they put forward the fire prevention plan for the season. I have also observed the tremendous dedication of these men and women, who not only make themselves available to fight fires in my electorate but attend road accidents, clear firebreaks and plan fundraising events to assist them to meet their goals as they set out to minimise fires within the region. Every year I hear stories involving acts of kindness and bravery as these people go about the job of fighting fires. One year not so long ago, I recall that local identity Harry Gratte received severe burns fighting a fire in Whiteman Park, and in fact he still bears the terrible scars after a couple of years of skin grafts. Harry is a very experienced volunteer firefighter and every year for many years he has put his life on the line, fighting fires not only in my electorate but in other areas. This year Harry was very lucky to escape with his life. The fire swept over his vehicle and it was only his long experience and quick action that saved his life. However, he was very severely burnt. On another occasion, I can recall sitting with Mr and Mrs Owston after fire swept through Wundowie and destroyed absolutely everything on their property: their home, their fences, their shed, their tools, their vehicles and their stock. Sadly, Mr Owston passed away just recently, but I shall never forget sitting with them on the back verandah, which was the only bit left standing, buckled and burnt, with a thermos of tea and Mr Owston giving an account of coming home, finding the property razed and then having to shoot 600 head of stock. These kinds of stories really bring home to you just how devastated people are when faced with these events. The loss of human life is bad enough, but people who work the land also feel it when they have to destroy their stock. Every year these tragic events are punctuated with acts of kindness and bravery, and I must say the community always responds very generously. At the beginning of this year, a fire in Lancelin claimed the life of a young volunteer firefighter from my electorate. That firefighter was Mr Craig Sandy. He was a young man with everything to live for. He was a dedicated volunteer. Sadly, he was killed when three fire appliances crashed as a huge blaze swept through Ledge Point and Lancelin, about 127 kilometres north of Perth, threatening homes and everything in its path. Mr Sandy was the captain of the Ocean Farm Volunteer Bushfire Brigade and the first summer fire victim in Western Australia. I understand he was to be married on Valentine’s Day, so my sympathy goes to his family and particularly to his fiancee. His death is a stark reminder of the risk that firefighters take in the voluntary work they do for the benefit of their communities. The Lancelin fire was a particularly bad fire. There were 100 firefighters working to contain the blaze, and it swept through a large area and threatened homes. People had to be evacuated, and some homes were lost. Alan and Nola Armstrong, from Wanneroo, were at Seaview in their holiday house when they noticed the fire. They started to hose the fire down, but eventually they had to evacuate as the flames drew closer. Mrs Armstrong said that a volunteer firefighter gave her a reassuring pat on the shoulder and said, ‘Don’t worry, we’ll look after your house.’ She said that they did and that it was really a fantastic effort. All the houses in Seaview were saved, and the firefighters not only threw all their energy into fighting this fire but used all the resources they possibly could to try to contain the fire. Their efforts were hampered when an emergency services communication tower was lost to the flames. They had a particularly difficult time. I congratulate them for the tremendous effort they put in. 11208 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 6 February 2003 With these tragic events happening every summer in Western Australia, particularly in the electorate of Pearce, we all watched with dismay as bushfires swept through other parts of the country, claiming the lives of other Australians. In Australia this year I understand that about 1.7 million hectares have been affected by fire and that about 550 homes were lost just here in the ACT. But, above all, it is the loss of people’s lives that is irreplaceable. We can always rebuild, but the real tragedy is the lives that have been lost in these fires and the suffering and pain that that has caused so many families and members of the community. The events in the ACT were particularly distressing. I know that constituents in my electorate of Pearce would want me to extend their deepest sympathy to those families affected by this tragedy, and that sympathy comes with a real understanding of the devastation of fire. I support the Prime Minister’s motion to the House which he made on Tuesday. It extends sympathy to all who have suffered throughout Australia personal loss through bushfires and acknowledges the tireless efforts of many individuals, including the rural and metro fire brigades. In my electorate, we have countless small communities, each of which has its own bushfire brigade which is run on a voluntary basis. As I said, these people do not just go out and fight fires; they do lots of other emergency work. They attend country road accidents. They do a lot of work each summer, knowing the history and that bushfires occur every year, with the community in trying to minimise the risk to members of the community from bushfires. On top of that, they raise funds to help to keep their units going. In his motion, the Prime Minister also thanked all of the emergency and rescue services and the ambulance service. In my electorate, which is made up of many small communities and country towns, this work is frequently done by volunteers. In fact, in the Pearce Australia Day awards, which I gave out, there were volunteer ambulance drivers and volunteer firefighters nominated by the community to receive awards. The Prime Minister also thanked Defence, the police, welfare groups, government agencies, councils and business. I want to pause just for a moment to say, again, businesses in the electorate of Pearce are extremely generous not only in providing equipment and donations but also in releasing their staff members to go and perform this voluntary work. That is a real contribution to the community and it sometimes goes unacknowledged. I would also like to add the property owners to my list of thanks. I know that in my electorate and certainly in the ACT there were people who not only stayed to fight the fires in their community, trying to prevent their own homes from being burnt down, but when they had done that job, often having lost the battle and lost their own homes, then turned their attention to helping their neighbours save their homes and to trying to save community facilities such as schools and other community buildings. I think these people also need to be acknowledged. There would be nothing more devastating than to be there trying to fight a fire on your own property with your own home threatened, watching it burn down and then having to focus your attention on helping to save your neighbour’s property or other community property. I would like to thank the many Australian people who made offers of assistance, sympathy, goods, accommodation and moral support, which is really very important for the people who were affected by these fires. During the fires, because obviously most of us who travel to Canberra to serve in this parliament know many people who live in Canberra, I made a few calls to people I knew to find out whether they were safe. I was told by the people I rang that they had never seen a community pull together in the way that people did here in the ACT over the days following the fire. Friends told me that many families went to the supermarket and filled up the shopping trolley with the object of delivering those goods to people who had lost everything in the fire. This was quite a common situation. Thursday, 6 February 2003 MAIN COMMITTEE 11209 There were countless stories of bravery, generosity and great kindnesses in the days following the fire. This is just part of the true Australian spirit. We can all feel very proud to live in a community where that community spirit is so evident and be enormously grateful for the kind hearts and warm personalities that I certainly encounter every day. We tend to be bombarded with all the bad things that are happening and all the negative accounts of what is going on in the community-robberies, old ladies being attacked and having their handbags stolen and houses being broken into-but we do not hear often enough about the tremendous acts of kindness and generosity and the unselfish actions carried out on behalf of so many in the community. To all those who have lent a hand and who have helped the community in some way and particularly to the volunteer firefighters in my electorate, who have been absolutely tremendous, I say thank you. Once again, on behalf of the Pearce electorate, I extend my sincere sympathies to those in the ACT who have lost friends and family in the fire and to those of other states who have been similarly devastated. Debate (on motion by Mr Murphy) adjourned. That the Main Committee do now adjourn. Environment: Global Warming berra but large areas of regional and urban Australia, while the unending drought brings ruin even to the best parts of our country. Once again, climatologists and CSIRO scientists are warning the government that the intensity and frequency of extreme weather conditions that provide opportunities for large-scale bushfires are directly linked to global warming, which is itself driven by greenhouse gas emissions. The evidence that the Prime Minister claims to have for the existence of Saddam Hussein’s arsenal is far more tenuous than the evidence linking the drought and bushfires to global warming. And yet, despite a lack of any substantial evidence, the government is willing to spend billions of dollars to send troops to Iraq while at the same time it claims that Australia cannot afford to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. If the government can argue that spending large sums of money on a war in Iraq is justified because of the possibility of the existence of chemical, biological or nuclear weapons, why can it not find the same amount of money for the protection of Australia from the ravages of greenhouse gas induced climate change? There is no doubt that a significant number of the frail, the sick and the elderly will have died as a result of the extreme temperatures of recent times. This does not include those tragically killed in recent bushfires around Australia. While the government cannot be blamed for these deaths, there is no doubt that they will bear a growing responsibility for future disasters if they continue to do nothing to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases. The evidence for the damaging effects of global warming continues to mount. The New Scientist of 18 January this year reports on new research that has uncovered a previously mysterious circulation pattern in the Pacific Ocean. Francisco Chavez from the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute has shown that the El Nino phenomenon follows a roughly 25-year cycle. The cycle alternates between many years with warm Pacific waters and strong El Ninos and many years with cooler waters and weaker El Ninos. In the years with stronger El Ninos, Australia experiences more severe droughts. Australia is presently in the grip of an unprecedented severe drought.

speaker: Mr Murphy (Lowe) (12.29 P.m.)
theText: Disastrous bushfires have devastated not only Can11210 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 6 February 2003 According to this new evidence, Pacific waters should be cooler and El Ninos should be significantly weaker. This tells us that a severe drought is not meant to be occurring at this time. Reviewing this new data, Frank Schwing of the Pacific Fisheries Environmental Laboratory in Pacific Grove, California, has speculated that global warming could spark a perpetual regime of severe El Ninos or ‘something even less welcome’. How much worse could things get? In answer to my question on notice No. 1202 to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage regarding the cost of implementing the Kyoto protocol, the minister replied: ... the annual costs of implementing the Kyoto Protocol range from a low of 0 to a high of 0.4 per cent of GNP at 2012. The minister’s own figures show that it would not significantly harm our economy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. These figures no doubt ignore the many savings that could be achieved if the analysis were not affected by the constraints imposed by the minister. An underlying, if unstated, principle that is often used to justify government defence spending is that no matter how small the threat there should be no constraints on the money spent to meet that threat. Why is this government so inconsistent? Why does the government maintain a head-in-the-sand approach to our environment? For how much longer will this government ignore the very large threat posed to Australia by global warming caused by greenhouse gas emissions? Dickson Electorate: Australia Day Awards would like today to pay tribute to the special group of people who were recently presented with Australia Day awards in Dickson. All the people I am about to speak about have given much of their time and energy to the Pine River Shire, to their local community groups and to those around them. Their achievements are in areas that range from sport and music to culture and voluntaryrism. At a ceremony of over 500 people, with 119 new Australians receiving their citizenship, it was wonderful for these great Australians to be honoured in front of those who had just decided to make this country their permanent home. The spirit of voluntaryrism is well and truly alive in Australia today, and I am proud that so many of my constituents in Dickson are willing participants in a variety of voluntary organisations, sporting clubs and community services. The first person I would like to mention today is Mr Doug Dohle, the 2003 Pine Rivers Citizen of the Year. Doug is the current president of the Pine Rivers Pony Club. As his wife and daughter will both tell you, Doug devotes much of his time to maintaining the grounds and facilities at the pony club and has done so for many years. Incidentally, Doug would also tell you that his wife and daughter provide great assistance not only to him but to the club and the general community. Doug Dohle is a most deserving winner of this award and is truly representative of the community spirit that he has encouraged through the massive amount of time and energy he has devoted to his local community. As with most people who are warded in such a way for their outstanding service, Doug would never have expected, let alone thought he was deserving of, such an award. But Doug is now the Pine Rivers Citizen of the Year and he is a most worthy recipient. He truly deserves this recognition and I congratulate him on his dedication to not only the Pine Rivers Pony Club but to the district in general. Like all award winners on Australia Day, Doug has a loving family who have always encouraged him and given him the opportunity to fulfil his desire of giving to others.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Dutton (Dickson) (12.33 P.m.)
theText: As I did this time last year in this parliament, IThursday, 6 February 2003 MAIN COMMITTEE 11211 Music is a vitally important component of many children’s development, and Mr Timo Jarvela is the inspiration who has ensured thousands of schoolchildren’s participation in music programs in Dickson, which is why he was awarded the cultural award on Australia Day. As an instrumental music teacher, Timo has continued to make the orchestras of Pine Rivers some of the best in the country. The children all love Timo as much as Timo loves teaching music. I congratulate Timo on his superb contribution to the musical community and wish him all the best for a great year ahead. As everybody in this parliament would be only too aware, sport plays a major role in our communities and is enjoyed by almost every Australian at some time in their life. This year, the Pine Rivers senior sportsperson of the year award was given to someone very special, someone who has overcome great obstacles to achieve in her chosen field: Mrs Mary Albrow. Mary, who is a transplant recipient, nearly drowned as a child but learnt to swim last year and in fact was placed in the swim events at the Transplant Games. I believe that Mary is a great example of what can be achieved at any age and that, if you really want to do something, anything can be achieved. Every person, regardless of their age, can take inspiration from Mary’s achievements and dedication. I congratulate Mary and thank her for inspiring our community. Swimming is quite obviously a very popular sport in Australia, as the Pine Rivers junior sportsperson of the year is also a swimmer. Jessicah Schipper, a 16-year-old from Murrumba Downs, in the northern part of the Dickson electorate, recently became only the third Australian woman to swim a 100-metre butterfly race in under one minute-an absolutely marvellous achievement. Jessicah has a huge future in front of her in the swimming pool, and I look forward to seeing her win gold for Australia at the Commonwealth and Olympic Games in the coming years. While it all looks too easy for some sports men and women, there are countless people who are not usually recognised for their contribution because they have not played in the winning team or, for that matter, in any team. They are the people who organise the fixtures, promote the sign-on days and run the clubs. In 2003, a very deserving Bruce Boland was named the Pine Rivers sports administrator of the year, for his contribution as vice-president at the Albany Creek Cricket Club. Bruce puts enormous amounts of time into the club through his administration, and is a great asset to the game. Without people like Bruce, our children could not be given the opportunity to participate in and play the sports they do. Every sporting and voluntary club in Australia needs a Bruce Boland to keep it moving. Some clubs will have someone like Bruce; some will not. I congratulate Bruce on this award and look forward to seeing many more great results from the Albany Creek Cricket Club next summer. This year the community event of the year award was given to a fabulous event in my community-the Albany Fair. I congratulate every person who helped with the organisation of that event for their time and effort, and I look forward to another great fair this coming year. I congratulate again all of the Australia Day award recipients. I thank them for contributing to and inspiring our community in Dickson, and I wish them all the very best for this year. Lilley Electorate: Australia Day Awards Many people celebrate their new life in our great nation. Perhaps in uncertain times many others celebrate the security and safety we share, as a fair and democratic nation. While plenty choose to make the most of the last long weekend before the new year truly kicks in, others choose not to celebrate but to reflect on our past treatment of our land’s traditional owners. On Australia Day, I choose to honour the great people in the electorate of Lilley. For the past eight years, I have shared our national day with the unsung heroes of our local community.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Swan (Lilley) (12.38 P.m.)
theText: Everybody celebrates different things on Australia Day.11212 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 6 February 2003 This year, the Lilley Australia Day Awards honoured 46 fantastic Australians-quiet achievers chosen by the Lilley Australia Day Awards Committee. While many of these people are strangers to each other, they have one overwhelming quality in common: they volunteer their time selflessly to the Lilley community. That is the essential criterion of the Lilley Australia Day Awards. These people donate their time and care to the community and ask for nothing in return. They see others needing help and they help them. They ask nothing more for themselves than the sheer pleasure of helping others. Our nation’s volunteers perform an incredible amount of work in the community. At this moment there are volunteers around the country in the Rural Fire Service ready to fight bushfires. Over the past few months state emergency services in practically every state have had to deal with the aftermath of the incredible devastation caused by fire. We saw it here only a few weeks ago. In my electorate there are volunteers like Charlie’s Angels at the Prince Charles Hospital in Chermside, who work tirelessly to cheer up the sick and free up valuable staff. Many volunteers in Lilley give their time to our schools. They work in the tuckshops, raise money with raffles and fetes, and help out with junior sports teams and parents’ associations so our children can get the best education we can provide them with. Countless numbers of Lilley’s senior citizens depend on the Meals on Wheels service from centres like Sandgate, Burnie Brae, Banyo, Chermside, Geebung and Crosby Park. Many in the veterans’ community likewise depend on the assistance that volunteers provide through RSL subbranches and organisations like the War Widows Guild which advocate on their behalf. They depend on people like Jack Mundy from the Geebung-Zillmere-Aspley-Bald Hills subbranch, who clocked up 50 years of service with the RSL this year. In Lilley we also have people like Jennifer Singfield, who has been involved in the Sea Scouts and the Keep Sandgate Beautiful project and has worked to clean up Cabbage Tree Creek; Sandra Clark, who has volunteered for Meals on Wheels for 20 years; Reg Cosgrove, who has given tireless assistance to young people; and Marlene Hatton, who has spent 25 years raising funds to assist World Vision. In my view, this is the type of person local communities want recognised on Australia Day. Our nation’s volunteers are the most important contributors to our nation’s well-being. They are the glue that holds the fabric of any community together. They are the glue that makes this country strong. They deserve recognition for their unpaid gift to our community. Therefore, it is disappointing to see so few of those who make the Australia Day honours list nominated for unpaid work. Indeed, when I searched the official 2003 Australia Day list on the Internet, I found only eight of 812 recipients cited with the words ‘volunteer’ or ‘voluntary’. In no way do I want to reflect on any of this year’s awardees. I am sure they are all very deserving. However, we should remember that the highest awards in the Australian honours system are regularly filled by those who are awarded for work they have been paid to dojudges, senior officials, doctors, lawyers, academics, sports people and politicians. They have all been paid to do this work. So legitimate questions ought to be asked, such as: how many of these people give something back to the community for nothing during their lives or after they conclude their well paid careers? Not too many. There should be more who do. I wonder about this. This year’s Lilley Australia Day Awards recognised my predecessor in this House, Mrs Elizabeth Grace. She has been recognised because, in the years since she left parliament, she has been serving the community in a senior citizens’ centre-the Golden Years at Nundah. I think she deserves the highest respect for this. The point is that I wish the high-flyers in our community and others who have been well paid and honoured would do the same. They ought Thursday, 6 February 2003 MAIN COMMITTEE 11213 to put something back into the community after they have been in well paid jobs and honoured for that. No doubt this year our Australian of the Year, Dr Fiona Stanley, has done that. Not only has she been paid over the years; she has also been a volunteer. We need more people in this category honoured in our national awards. We need more people like these quiet achievers, who are not being paid for their work, that we have honoured in the Lilley Australia Day Awards. The system needs a dramatic shake-up, and there needs to be a much bigger emphasis on voluntary efforts. (Time expired) Makin Electorate: Automobile Industry the member for Lilley has just said in this chamber. I thank him for his acknowledgment of former member Mrs Elizabeth Grace. TodayI would like to talk about the automobile industry. It is the largest manufacturing industry in South Australia, directly employing more than 13,000 people in my home state. Of the more than 350,000 cars made in Australia each year, around half are manufactured in South Australia at the Holden and Mitsubishi plants. In addition, more than 40 component manufacturers supply the car industry with tyres, steel and alloy wheels, engine components, rear view mirrors, seats, suspension modules, mouldings and exhaust systems. On Saturday, 25 January, I had the honour of representing the federal government at the announcement by Holden of its intention to employ a further 1,000 people at its Elizabeth plant. The announcement by Holden of a third shift confirms how important the Elizabeth plant is to Holden and to the Australian industry. The plant is the heart of the Holden enterprise. It employs more than 4,000 local people in assembling 28 locally produced models. Of great importance to the South Australian economy, it is of particular importance to the economic and social well-being of the people of the northern and north-eastern suburbs of Adelaide, many of whom live within my electorate of Makin. The massive expansion program will enable Holden to pursue new export opportunities and increase the number of models produced at the Elizabeth plant from 28 to 35. Last year, Holden confirmed its position as the leading car manufacturer in Australia-it achieved an all-time record with sales of more than 178,000 vehicles, including more than 88,000 Commodores. That represents almost 22 per cent of the new vehicle market. Holden’s success in the domestic market is being matched by its growing presence in international markets. In 2001, Holden sold almost $1.2 billion worth of exports. One of the most exciting breakthroughs last year was the announcement that Holden would begin selling its award winning Monaro to the United States, re-badged as the legendary Pontiac GTO. American car industry leaders saw in Holden a company that could provide new, exciting models in an otherwise stale US market. The creation of 1,000 new jobs at Holden’s Elizabeth plant will be a tremendous injection into the local economy. The Howard government has been, and will continue to be, a strong partner in the success of Holden and our other Australian car manufacturers. In 1997, the Howard government announced a tariff freeze and a five-year $2.8 billion program of assistance to support the car industry to become more competitive. Only a few weeks before the Holden announcement, the Howard government announced the next stage in its long-term plans for the car industry. This second stage boosts industry assistance to an unprecedented $4.2 billion and will see the industry through to 2015. When that program ends, the Howard government will have given the industry 15 years of certainty and $7 billion in support. No-

speaker: Mrs Draper (Makin) (12.44 P.m.)
theText: On this occasion I could not agree more with what11214 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 6 February 2003 one could credibly argue that this government is not doing enough to support the automobile industry in Australia. The results of this policy speak for themselves. Australian cars are being produced in greater numbers than eight years ago. Our exports of automotive products have tripled since 1996 and are worth almost $5 billion-and the industry is predicting it will achieve $10 billion in exports by 2010. Last year was a record year for the industry as a whole, with almost 825,000 new vehicles sold. The quality of Australian cars has vastly improved and, perhaps for the first time, is genuinely world class. The success of our exports in more than 30 countries worldwide confirms that our industry is a world beater. I know that the workers at the Elizabeth plant, many of whom are my constituents, take pride in their work. They should know that they are contributing to the success of one of the most important industries in Australia. As their federal representative, I was pleased to have had the opportunity to welcome Holden’s latest expansion at its Elizabeth plant. The confidence expressed by Holden in the future of the industry in South Australia is a great boost to the local community and a sure sign that the policies of the Howard government are bringing great benefits to the people of Makin. Trade: Free Trade Agreement been causing me concern for some time-that is, the proposed Australia-US free trade agreement, or FTA. I would like to place on the record that I am not against free trade. The liberalisation of trade barriers over last two decades has greatly expanded the Australian economy and has, I believe, contributed to wealth generation in Australia. I do have concerns with a number of issues regarding this FTA. Firstly, I am concerned about the secretive approach to the progress of negotiations, creating suspicions in the community as to the trade-offs that are now being negotiated. Secondly, I am concerned about the effects that this agreement may have on a number of our industries, particularly those in the services sector. Thirdly, I am concerned that our strong trade relationships with our neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region could be unduly affected by an FTA between Australia and the US. I was disturbed to hear earlier last month that the government has been involved in secretand I emphasise the word ‘secret’-discussions and has refused to open up public debate on this issue. I would have thought that this proposed FTA was of such economic importance to the country that the Australian public should have the ability to make worthwhile contributions to the debate. The US has had no such difficulties with opening the FTA negotiations to public debate in their country. The US Trade Representative, Robert Zoellick, has provided a briefing to the Congress and submissions have opened, with various interest groups raising their concerns about a number of issues. Notably, the most vocal of these people were those involved in the agricultural sector. US farmers involved in the beef, sugar, dairy and grain industries have all demanded that Australian imports in those industries be subject to significant barriers to entry. It is no secret that our agricultural sector is the most efficient in the world, and American farmers fear that our lower cost and better quality products entering the US market may prove to be more competitive in the marketplace. The US dairy industry went as far as to say, ‘Opening the US market to Australian dairy farmers could endanger US security.’ The US agricultural sector has a very strong political influence and has been influential in the election of the Bush administration in 2000 and the success of the Republican Party in the recent Congressional elections. This sector has won significant concessions from the Bush

speaker: Mrs Crosio (Prospect) (12.49 P.m.)
theText: I would like to speak today on an issue that hasThursday, 6 February 2003 MAIN COMMITTEE 11215 administration and, with growing political support from farmers, I doubt that the administration would concede much to Australian farmers. Reportedly, the US has made some demands of its own that would impact significantly on a number of our most important industries. Issues for the US include the winding back of the single desk for Australian wheat and Australia’s strong quarantine laws, greater access to our broadcasting services, government services and the health and education sectors. Robert Zoellick has been placing significant pressure on the Canadians to abolish their single desk arrangements and has stated on the public record that the US wants the abolition of all monopoly powers held by state enterprises. The National Farmers Federation is rightly concerned about this threat. The huge US companies that dominate the global pharmaceutical industry have also placed significant pressure on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, the PBS. Industry lobbyist Joe Damond told public hearings into the FTA that the PBS prohibited the freedom of pharmaceutical companies to charge higher prices for new products on the market and they were concerned about the subsidies of a number of popular products that, in their minds, should be more profitable. The PBS is an important part of the Australian public policy framework, and has been for half a century. It has made medicines affordable for people who would otherwise have to suffer just because they are poor. We cannot and must not allow this to be traded off. The US also would like the Foreign Investment Review Board to be abolished. Our education sector is also on the agenda so that rich American kids can easily obtain a quality Australian education. The truth is that Australia will not obtain the same concessions from the US. How can we? The Australian economy is only one twenty-fifth of the size of the American economy. California has a larger economy that Australia has. Our negotiating power is limited, and we have to be careful about the motives of the companies that are strongly supporting this. These companies include General Motors, Citigroup, and Proctor and Gamble. All of this is occurring at a time when we are suffering a fall in exports to our most important trading region, East Asia. In the last 12 months, merchandise exports to that region have fallen by 3.7 per cent, and this is at a time when there has been economic growth in the region of five per cent. The argument that this is due to the drought does not stack up, and the argument that it is due to an international recession does not either. The truth is that this government has decided to let fade away the diversification programs of the previous Labor government. Labor developed a program that would see Australia able to export with strength even in times of drought. The international markets could view Australia as more than an agricultural and commodity based economy. The reason our dollar has been so low is that we are again viewed as a farm and a quarry. (Time expired) Bushfires Ms LEY (Farrer) (12.54 p.m.)-I wish to speak today about the fires that have ravaged parts of my electorate of Farrer. The Snowy Mountains townships of Talbingo, Khancoban and especially the tiny town of Cabramurra, Australia’s highest town, were under threat. Thousands of acres of pine plantations, including many trees that are 30 years old, could have gone up in smoke. The Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Authority sustained considerable damage to its communications systems and roads network, with some direct damage to power stations but thankfully nowhere near as much as there could have been. The Khancoban water catchment has been burnt out and the town of Tumbarumba was threatened. Tumbarumba is on emergency water supplies. Fires that might have negatively impacted upon the regional economy are now well and truly under control. But of course only a really brave soul would say that it is all over, because storms are forecast for later this week 11216 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 6 February 2003 and we are still well and truly in the grip of the fire season. We now have to concentrate on the task of recovery and we have to thank members of the community for what they have done for the forests, the towns and for each other, whether it was in an official or unofficial capacity. There will be long-term effects that we cannot yet determine on our forestry and forest products industries which harvest from the area between Tumut, Tumbarumba and Canberra-not forgetting that the whole of the Victorian high country is burning. Kosciusko National Park, an Australian icon, has been burnt beyond recognition. As much as three-quarters of the total park, part of which is in my electorate and part of which is in the electorate of Eden-Monaro, is gone. Flying over the forests on the way up to Canberra, the desolation is striking. The heat of the fires has obviously been extraordinarily intense in some parts, so much so that the trees are just ashen sticks. Even from 9,000 feet high you can see clearly the ground between them, black and wasted and such wide expanses of it. Never has our native bush seemed so fragile or so vulnerable and the point is that it is all lost; it is just not there any more. To say that it has been burnt could imply that it has been damaged but it will recover. It has not been damaged; it has been lost. It was quite apparent that there was nothing moving and nothing alive down there, nor would there be for a very long time. People may be used to the rapid regeneration that we experienced after the Sydney bushfires, but it will not be the case here. This country is colder. The terrain is steep, rugged and inhospitable. The subsoil will wash away along with rocks and sticks and will damage our waterways. My immediate response, perhaps not quite logical, was that I felt that as custodians of our natural environment we have visited a terrible destruction on it and we have done very wrong, and I just felt very sorry. The community as a whole has much to learn from these fires. We need a renewed appreciation of the power of the natural world in which we live and we need to recognise that the human race has no choice but to adapt our world and ourselves to strike a balance which serves the interests of both. I believe the balance has tipped too far towards not interfering with nature and towards allowing extremes of untouched wilderness to prevail. We know that wilderness is precious, but we should know that it is unnatural for it not to burn. Areas of the park exploded from treetop to treetop, within areas normally too wet to burn. This was an exceptional fire: fuel reduction and grazing on high country leases would not have prevented it, but they would have improved our chances of fighting it. A slow, cool burn allows animals to escape, usually high in the trees as it moves through the undergrowth. Perhaps the procedure the park management needs to undergo to conduct hazard reduction burns needs to be looked at. I understand the approval process takes weeks and I have no doubt this reflects community hesitation over regular widespread controlled burning but in a temperate rainforest like Kosciusko, the window of opportunity is small and the local management needs to be able to act decisively and swiftly. The equivalent of many years of forestry logging allocation in New South Wales has been destroyed by these bushfires. In New South Wales there are 516 parks and reserves. Two hundred and thirty-seven of these need fire management plans, but to date only 10 of these plans have been made public. New South Wales does not have a management plan for the Brindabella National Park and, on the New South Wales parks and wildlife web site, under the fire management section for Kosciusko, it states that at present the service has insufficient resources to undertake the full range of fire management responsibilities. Three hundred and thirty thousand hectares of the park have been burnt. But I understand the plan is under review and that fire management will be considered a priority. I know that those who conduct such reviews are people who have the best interests of the park at heart. If there are lessons to Thursday, 6 February 2003 MAIN COMMITTEE 11217 be learned, I am sure they will be. This is not a criticism of the people who work within the organisation. We all labour under excessive rules and regulations. I encourage the New South Wales government to allocate more resources in this vital area and to listen to the wise views of local people. Taxation the House of Representatives Notice Paper, directed to the Treasurer. That question, No. 43, states: What percentage of barristers and solicitors pay the top marginal rate of income tax? Despite a number of speeches and requests to the Speaker over the last 12 months, Treasurer Costello refuses to answer this question. I am aware that in his possession at the moment is a report, following the laudable revelations by Paul Barry in the Sydney Morning Herald about the abuse visited on the taxation system by barristers, and that the Assistant Treasurer and the Attorney-General know that 80 per cent of barristers do not pay the top marginal rate of tax. Something has got to be done about it. Main Committee adjourned at 1.00 p.m.

Immigration: Detention Centres (Question No. 1273) Ms Gillard asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 2002: (1) Is the Minister aware of allegations that the contractor responsible for the drainage works at the immigration detention facility at Baxter removed a number of trees on and around the site. (2) Has this site been subject to re-afforestation efforts, with assistance from Greening Australia, in recent years. (3) Was the contractor required to rethink its approach to the drainage. (4) What was the additional cost caused by the contractor having to re-do the drainage arrangements. (1) The drainage contractor removed a handful of small trees and shrubs from the area where the accommodation compounds were to be located and a number of salt-bush shrubs for the construction of a sewage evaporation pond. The location of services and buildings was planned to minimise the removal of trees and shrubs. A small number of trees and several shrubs were required to be removed as part of installation of the physical security arrangements. This work was undertaken by a separate contractor. Under an agreement with the Department of Defence initiated by my department, each tree and shrub removed is to be replaced at a ratio of 2 to 1.
